advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NLS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert from Non-Linear Systems, dated July, 1982 for the KAYCOMP II that was not still called KAYPRO. <br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"><b>A WORD ABOUT NLS</b><br> Non-Linear Systems, inc. is the originator of the digital voltmeter and an innovative leader in the field of electronic test equipment.<br> Organized in 1952, NLS has been a major supplier of digital voltmeters and ratiometers to large corporations in the aerospace industry. Since 1972, NLS has been consumer directed, providing small, portable multimeters, oscilloscopes, counters, frequency meters, temperature meters. And now, NLS has entered the world of computers with one though - to provide the best value in a small, business, scientific and family computer.</font><br><br> Standard software delivered with the KAYCOMP II: <br><br> - <b>CP/M 2.2</b> - operating system<br> - <b>S/BASIC</b> - Structured Basic compiler<br> - <b>PROFIT PLAN</b> - Electronic worksheet<br> - <b>SELECT</b> - Complete word processing system<br> - <b>TEACH</b> - A self-teaching guide to SELECT </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>In July 1985, California Digital sold the Tano at $99. The price would decrease down to $35 while stock last.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD (SEPT. 87)</strong></font><br><blockquote>It is unlikely that this hideous advert helped early sales of the Archimedes.<br> It said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Acorn are proud to announce the fastest micros in the world * The Archimedes high performance Computer Systems * Using a 32 bit RISC chip, Archimedes represents a breakthrough in microprocessing technology allowing a new order of magnitude in power...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #6</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to datareign.co.uk for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Hard disk version<br><br> "<font color="#666666">No matter how you look at it, KAYPRO is the best value you will see anawhere...</font>"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the computing answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PICTURE (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used for promoting Educatel, a French private computing school.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is one of the first adverts showing a one computer dedicated software range. In 1979, the computer manufacturers understood that it was not enough any more to sell hardware and that the success of a computer depended now on the range and quality of the software that came with it.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The simple fact is nobody - nobody in the personal computer industry - offers more software than Ohio Scientific! Right now, as you read this, Ohio Scientific has just about 2 million bytes of software available for our C4P MF computer.</font> <br><br> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> adds:<br><font color="#666666"> I'd like to mention that Aardvark Software in Michigan was one of the better vendors of software for the C4P games.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> THINKJET ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>August 1985</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #3 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The guy on the right is "Sidney", a well known french break dancer back in 1984 !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HARD WORKING MAN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture shows a man smiling while looking at his personal account...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #9</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the competition is dumb !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this funky ??!! I love it. We can see here the handle of the H1.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Maxi Basic Yeno SC 3000 : program at full gallop"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dealer price list - August 1986</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Two generations amazed...</b> <br><br> Perhaps a bit too much though... but the scene is beautiful and we can only admire the originality of the Philips' communication campaign which, for once, is not exclusively focused on the young Basic apprentices.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>

computer.description:
The Hewlett Packard HP 9000 is the ancestor of the actual HP9000 station!
The RAM can be extended by blocks of 128 Kb. It is possible to add one or two processors (its power is then brought to 1.7 mips or 2.5 mips). It runs under HP-UX (Unix) and is sold with a database (image 9000), a 3D graphic program (graph 9000), as well as the BASIC, Pascal, FORTRAN and C programming languages.
There was a later variant with a 68010 processor that supported HP-UX (the HP version of Unix). It was called the 9836U. There were color versions of both, the 9836C and the 9836CU.
Marks Simms reports that the system HP that was sold as the first 32-bit microcomputer was the 9020. It was based on HP's proprietary processor architecture. The 9020 was a desktop system, but was much larger than the 9836 and had only one floppy drive. It only ran HP-UX.
After these products had been launched, HP decided to give the HP 9000 name to all its technical computers and the 9836 became the HP 9000 model 236 and the 9020 became the HP 9000 model 520. Add the series 300, 700 and 800 and the term HP 9000 becomes almost meaningless.
The Series 200 included the HP-9816, HP-9826, HP-9836, and HP-9836C. The HP-9836 was mainly used for CAE applications, and high-technology (of that time !) in general.
Alan Barrow reports : The 9020 was HP's 32 bit workstation prior to the switch to motorola processors. The 9020 started like the 9836 as basic, but was quickly refocused to HP-UX. It then became the 9000 Series 500. The later 9030 and 9050 offered more expansion and utilized CIO bus cards later used in the first S800's.
The Series 500 was a true multi user unix environment and was used both in workstation and mini-computer type environment.
One more family note: some of the S200's unix executables would work on the Integral in character mode as well. In fact, they would also work on the S300's in 16 bit mode, I believe. HP did a good job of trying to maintain compatability via standards.
computer.keyboard: full stroke keyboard with numeric keypad and function keys
computer.name: HP-9836
